dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A barren landscape that stretches forever, flat-topped me in the distant background. No buildings, no people...only lonely wind that stirs the dust from the desert floor

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: There is a story told in the town of Big Lake, Texas. A story of the town’s beginnings... An ancient OIL RIG comes into view; long since dried up, tumbleweeds choking its foundation.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (V.O,)
dialogues.text: It is the story of the Santa Rita number one, the birthplace of west Texas oil. As with most oil legends, there was a man who believed oil was right beneath his feet, and, as with most oil legends, there was no one who believed him. The wind swirls the dust higher, and as it settles...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...TWO NUNS, each holding a BASKET OF YELLOW ROSE PETALS.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Except, in this case, for two nuns, who in 1923 believed in the man’s dream and were willing to invest money no one knew they had. Their priest shook his head and offered only one small piece of advice. The nuns toss a handful cf the petals high into the sky.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Bless the site with rose petals of yellow and invoke the help of Saint Rita, the patron saint of impossible dreams. The petals flutter to the ground...and in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...€@ BASEBALL FIELD, more accurately a patch of dirt. Oi workers are playing a baseball game...and playing well. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: Played baseball so well that some were able to give up the dirt and the despair, and went on to play major league ball in the glory days of Ruth and Gehrig. The oil worker tosses a pitch and the batter HITS IT high very high, into the air. And while the ball flies lazy in the dusty air, the blue turns. gray and the dust turns into snowflakes.

dialogues.text: Besides...he smoked three packs a day.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: CAL
dialogues.text: Nat King Cole. Thought it made his voice deeper.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Oh...and Sinatra was the poster child for vocal care?

dialogues.speaker: CAL
dialogues.text: Who died in his 40‘s? You take care of yourself...things work out.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, well what about Jimmy? He took good care of himself. How many surgeries was it, Jimmy? Four? Jimmy doesn't have to answer. They all know that’s the number .

dialogues.speaker: HUNTER
dialogues.text: They put this thing from his ankle up in his shoulder. The three men cringe.

dialogues.speaker: CAL
dialogues.text: We're talkin’ about singin’, not pitchin’. And, Hunter, do us a favor and don't tell us that bit about the ankle anymore. 20. 29 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: tenn

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: FRANK Qo Mel Torme. In June. \

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: What...are you talking about now?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Mel Torme wrote The Christmas Song. On a beach somewhere. Jack Frost wasn’t nippin’ at any noses that day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy and Hunter walk to the truck, the rest of the parki spots empty.

dialogues.speaker: HUNTER
dialogues.text: Dad? (Jimmy waits for the question) Your arm ever hurt anymore?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Only when I drag you out of bed in the morning for school. {sees Hunter was serious) I was just kiddin’ bud. It hasn‘t hurt : for a long time, (

dialogues.speaker: HUNTER
dialogues.text: How long?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Where’s this comin’ from?

dialogues.speaker: HUNTER
dialogues.text: I was just wonderin’. They get in the truck.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Let's see. It never hurt in high school ‘cause we didn‘t have a team. Never hurt in junior college, which is why I got * drafted... (long beat) -.-and then,.. it started hurtin’. ™

dialogues.speaker: HUNTER
dialogues.text: That why you didn’t make it?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: It‘s never one thing. aon

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jimmy starts the truck and brings an end to the conversat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy’s driving back home, Hunter already fast asleep nex him. He slows down as he sees the field where he played h American Legion ball as a young man. Jimmy pulls the truck to a stop and keeps the headlights to illuminate the pitching mound. He gets out, softly closing the door so as not to disturb son, and reaches in the truck bed. In one hand, a glove; the other, a BURLAP SACK. Jimmy gets to the mound, not a soul in sight, and pulls a baseball from the sack. His arm stretches out, loosening, and then he casually to a pitch toward home. Nothing more than a lazy pitch, a routine that for Jimmy way to relax...the same as reading might be for others. The pattern repeats. Silhouette. The ball clanging into t chain-link backstop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A baby's cry cuts through the 4:10 AM darkness; not a pai cry, just the one telling Mom and Dad it’s time to get up Lorri tosses the covers aside and groans as she looks at clock. Jimmy stirs as if he might be getting up.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I'll get her.

dialogues.speaker: LORRI
dialogues.text: Is this a real “I'll get her”...or are you waitin’ for me to say “go back to sleep.”

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I haven‘t decided.

dialogues.speaker: LORRI
dialogues.text: Go back to sleep. INT. JAMIE’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 33 Lorri picks up JAMIE, eight months old, and starts to com her. She turns and sees a sleepy Jimmy in the door. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY .
dialogues.text: I need to get up anyway {

dialogues.speaker: LORRI
dialogues.text: What you need is more sleep.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: (doesn’t protest) Okay . He starts to turn..

dialogues.speaker: LORRI
dialogues.text: How'd everything go last night?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Sammy took me deep and Hunter and I got to ten to Frank and Cal argue about whether Nat King Cole was a better singer than Frank Sinatra.

dialogues.speaker: LORRI
dialogues.text: I thought they already had that argument?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: (heading out the door) ‘Bout once a week. See ya in an hour. ¢ Lorri smiles and settles into a rocking chair with Jamie, quietly singing a lullabye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy enters his classroom, but it’s too early for any of students to be there. Instead...he finds PRINCIPAL PHIL MCKINNEY, 50, VERY TEXA using a chemistry burner to warm his cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Morning Phil ,

dialogues.speaker: MCKINNEY
dialogues.text: Mornin’ Jim. There ain’t nuthin’ over here gonna hurt me, is there?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Besides that coffee?

dialogues.speaker: MCKINNEY
dialogues.text: Been Principal for ten years (turns the flame off ..still waitin’ for a decent cup. (

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: (knows he’s there for a reason) What's up?

dialogues.speaker: MCKINNEY
dialogues.text: Thought we might go for a walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McKinney and Jimmy stroll down the hallway, heading for t main doors to the school.

dialogues.speaker: MCKINNEY
dialogues.text: You hear I had to bring the kids in yesterday?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Snakes?

dialogues.speaker: MCKINNEY
dialogues.text: Sewer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McKinney and Jimmy walk in the outfield of the dried-up h school baseball field

dialogues.speaker: MCKINNEY
dialogues.text: Jimmy, I‘ve always been honest with my teachers...‘cause it’s the only way I know. Jimmy says nothing, listening

dialogues.speaker: MCKINNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We gave baseball a try a few years back, basically as a way to keep some of the kids busy between basketball and football. (beat) Football’s religion and the basketball program's done fine. {a short pause) Fact of the matter is...we aren’t seein’ much when it comes to baseball.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: We got a good group comin’ back.

dialogues.speaker: MCKINNEY
dialogues.text: ..-you got ten kids who were lucky to win one game last year. That ain't much of a team. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jimmy bites his lip and looks away. Both men come to a st

dialogues.speaker: MCKINNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: One of these kids breaks an arm...or their parents have to up and leave because the oil's dried up... {knows it’s hurting Jimmy) ...we can’t play.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: You sayin’ what I think you're sayin’? McKinney‘s silence answers the question. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Phil...the only two things that keep this town goin’ are oil and ranching. And ever since I’ve been here, one of the two's been dried up. (McKinney smiles at the truth) Now they both are. It’s Phil’s turn to listen.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Baseball's the only thing some of these kids have. Don’t take it away too.

dialogues.speaker: MCKINNEY
dialogues.text: (waits a moment before...) S'your team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NINE PLAYERS are scattered around the field, most wearing their year-old BIG LAKE OWL TEE SHIRTS. Jimmy has a bat over his shoulder and an EQUIPMENT BAG in hand as he walks to the plate. A TENTH PLAYER runs up...

dialogues.speaker: TENTH PLAYER
dialogues.text: Coach...I forgot my glove. Without a word and without breaking stride, Jimmy hands h the bag. The young player starts pawing through it.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: {to himself) Ten players. Nine gloves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hunter shadows his father, as he always does. He props th bats just so against the fence, making certain the battin helmets are in a precise line.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY

dialogues.speaker: JOEL
dialogues.text: Couple of holes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: Let's get one. RUDY, 17, scoops up the ball and. tosses it to first base where JOE DAVID, 17, catches it.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Still waitin’ for the seed to take. ..and he sends a lazy grounder to shortstop. JOAQUIN, 17, HISPANIC, is down on one knee, giving the infield dirt a over. The bail skips right over his head

dialogues.speaker: JOAQUIN
dialogues.text: What seed? Jimmy doesn’t even turn to his catcher, but mutters to hi

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: One of the holes?

dialogues.text: Yes sir. The ball trickles into the outfield.

dialogues.speaker: JOAQUIN
dialogues.text: Ain't no grass seed here. He stands up...

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Joaquin... The ball sizzles in from the outfield, but Joaquin’s kick the dirt in front of him. Jimmy yells out his nickname. . JIMMY (CONT’D) Wack! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ..and Joaquin casually turns just as the ball arrives fro the outfield. Had he not turned, it might have hit him in back of the head, but instead...hé snags it effortlessly.

dialogues.speaker: JOAQUIN
dialogues.text: (tosses it home) How come we get dirt...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He points to the football field across the street, sprink lazily spraying water on the lush carpet of green.

dialogues.speaker: JOAQUIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ..and the football field looks like Tiger Woods’ backyard?

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: They don‘t even play for six months. dimmy sends another grounder toward short...a sharp one.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Hey guys? Why don’t you let me worry about the field... This time the ball rolls through Wack’s legs, his hands o his hips.

dialogues.speaker: JOAQUIN
dialogues.text: You plan on worryin’ anytime soon? Jimmy’s patience runs thin.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Wack, what do you say you get some of your runnin’ in early today.

dialogues.speaker: JOAQUIN
dialogues.text: Yeah...I‘11 get my runnin’ in. He drops his glove in a manner suggesting it’s not the fi time this has happened. Wack takes off in a lazy jog toward the outfield, kicking dirt and sarcastically coughing as he goes. Jimmy has to suppress a smile. He hits another ground ball...

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Alright, let’s bring it home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The players are gone, all except for Jimmy, Joel and Hunt Joel is stacking his gear, while Jimmy gathers some stray baseballs by the mound. Hunter bags everything else.

dialogues.speaker: JOEL
dialogues.text: Hey Coach? (Jimmy looks over) You wanna throw? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOEL
dialogues.text: Hey Coach? (Jimmy looks over) You wanna throw? Simmy stands up, dropping the last ball in the burlap bag

dialogues.text: I've seen you out at the Legion Field. at night. (beat } Y¥‘know sometimes if you throw...works - better if you got somebody catchin’. Joel tosses a ball a couple of feet in the air. It Pplops his glove.

dialogues.text: Joel catches one of the warm-up tosses. It’s nothing spec producing nothing more than a soft THUD as it hits the gl

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I dunno. Eighty-four... eighty-five. Hunter settles in on the bleachers to watch his father.

dialogues.text: That's not bad. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOEL
dialogues.text: Let‘s see you bring one.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Can‘t. Promised too many doctors.

dialogues.speaker: JOEL
dialogues.text: C'mon man...one's not gonna hurt ya.. {opens and closes mitt) Feed me. Jimmy catches the ball and holds it for a second. Joel di his cleats in, his glove a tempting invitation. Hunter leans forward, curious. Joel nods and Jimmy sizzle pitch across the plate. It hits Joel‘s glove with a loud POPPING sound. Joel is motionless, holding the ball right where it hit. he shakes his mitt - his hand hurts.

dialogues.speaker: JOEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Whoa. (he stands to toss it back) Where’d that come from? Jimmy catches the ball. His eyes are in a different time.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Forgot how good that sounded. Joel settles back in...and there is... ...a flurry of pitches: Pop...pop...THWACK. Each crushing into the catcher’s glove. One last pop. Joel stands and w to the mound.

dialogues.text: How fast you think those were comin‘?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Not as fast as you think. (beat) Do me a favor...lets keep this one between us.

dialogues.text: Sure. Hunter arrives at the mound on Joel’s last word.

dialogues.text: I could barely see that last one!

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Goes for you too. No tellin’ Mom, okay?

dialogues.speaker: HUNTER
dialogues.text: How come?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: That’s my job, that’s how come.

dialogues.text: Lorri sits on a blanket, trying to make sure the stack of papers she‘s working on doesn’t blow away. Jamie’s asleep just behind her. Hunter zips by, fast enough that he takes a few of the pa with him. Jimmy, not zipping, is a couple of strides behi

dialogues.text: Daddy!

dialogues.text: Grandpa pushed me way high!

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I saw. Jimmy glances at his father and the distance between the is obvious. Jimmy puts Jessica down. JIMMY (CONT’D) Jessie hon, why don‘t you go see if your mom needs any help with Jamie. She scampers away JIM SR. They‘re growin‘ fast.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Kids have a way of doin’ that. JIM SR. (nods) Things okay at school? He‘s trying, but Jimmy won‘t nibble.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Things are fine. Hunter‘s really reaching to the sky.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hunter, bring it down a bit bud.

dialogues.text: But Dad...

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I said...bring it down! JIM SR. He‘s okay. Jimmy carefully holds his hand out to slow Hunter down, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: an

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let's see what kind of food your mom‘s hidin‘ from us up there

dialogues.text: But I just got started.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: We can do some more aiter dinner. Disappointed, Hunter trudges off toward the blanket and J turns to follow his son. Jim Sr. stays behind...and watch them walk away. 42A EXT. MORRIS HOME - NIGHT 42a ESTABLISHING SHOT of Jim and Lorri‘’s home.

dialogues.text: Jimmy and Lorri sit on the steps of their front porch. He his arm draped around her and she leans against him. Both hold GLASSES OF WINE

dialogues.speaker: LORRI
dialogues.text: Your dad's tryin’ hon. Tryin’ to straighten out a lot of things.

dialogues.text: Why don‘t you straighten out the rest of that bottle. She reaches for the bottle and pours the last of it. JimMy (CONT'D) Nothing like wine bought with a Chevron credit card. Lorri puts the bottle down.

dialogues.speaker: LORRI
dialogues.text: Well =I know what a demanding consumer you can be.

dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: LORRI
dialogues.text: Mmhmm . Lorri rests her head on Jimmy’s shoulder again. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: 324 43 CONTINUED: a3

dialogues.text: I threw today ..and she quickly sits upright, turning. ..concerned

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I threw today. ...an@ she quickly sits upright, turning...concerned. JIMMY (CONT’D) To Joel. After practice.

dialogues.text: You threw? How hard? Jimmy remembers how good it felt. He wants her to know th but he also doesn’t want her worrying.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Pretty hard. There‘s no settling back on his shoulder, not for awhile. much for not worrying.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll stop if it starts hurtin’. Promise. Lorri gets up and opens the screen door.

dialogues.speaker: LORRI
dialogues.text: I gotta check on the kids.

dialogues.text: The season opener. Jimmy encourages his team from the dug while the rest of the players sit on the bench.

dialogues.text: C'mon Rudy! The baseball field is still dusty, the stands almost empt The pitcher on the opposing team tosses a pitch and Rudy watches it go by.

a ro 35.

dialogues.text: Jimmy walks down the hallway, classroom paperwork from af the game tucked under his arm. He passes the JANITOR, already pushing his broom.

dialogues.speaker: JANITOR
dialogues.text: {quietly as Jimmy passes) I know why your grass isn’t growing. Jimmy stops...and looks back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The janitor flicks on a BANK OF LIGHTS and THREE DEER, no even considering running, raise their heads. A couple seconds later they drop their heads and resume nibbling away at the baseball field.

dialogues.text: Usually get three or four out here every night.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: So I put the seed down...they pick it up.

dialogues.speaker: JANITOR
dialogues.text: Once it comes in, they don’t like it as much. S'why the football field looks good.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Yeah...oc maybe the football guys are payin’ these deer off with all that budget money.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (yells) Hey! Go on...get outta here! JIMMY (CONT’D) Thought deer were s‘posed to be skittish. INT. HENRY‘’S STORE - DAY Henry, Frank and Cal are playing cards. Jimmy sits table, but is content to sip on a cup of coffee.

dialogues.text: How many these job applications you plannin’ to send out?

dialogues.text: (shakes his head) The young man who bought socks from me after a dozen moves. Thinkin’ of movin’ himself.

dialogues.text: That was different.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Always is. Henry examines his cards as he sorts them all out. at the
47 48 (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Jimmy, I hear you have diagnosed the problem with that baseball field of yours.

dialogues.speaker: CAL
dialogues.text: You mean his potential field.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Diagnosed part‘s right. It’s the curin’' part I’m havin’ trouble with. Cal looks at Frank.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I‘1l take five.

dialogues.text: Same thing happened at my place couple of springs back.

dialogues.text: Yeah? What’d you do?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (nods to Cal) Five. {to Jimmy) How many games you have on that field, next couple of weeks?

dialogues.speaker: CAL
dialogues.text: (deals himself} .-.I do believe I'll take five myself

dialogues.text: We play there on Friday, then we‘re not back till the end of the month.

dialogues.speaker: CAL
dialogues.text: (knocks on the table) Pot's right.

dialogues.text: Can you keep your boys off it that long? Practice and everything?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Henry, why do I think this is somethin’ I don’t wanna know abour

dialogues.text: ='m gonna use two of my old ones, if that’s alright with everyone. Frank grabs two of his old cards. Nobody blinks.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Tell you what. Give me three weeks, I‘11 have that field greener than Dublin on Saint Patrick‘’‘s Day. {tosses some chips in) And I promise...1‘1l only ask for one thing in return.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few minutes from the start of practice...and the boys a goofing off. Joe David tosses a wild pitch from the mound wild enough that Wack almost has to jump to swing at it.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: (walking toward the mound) Where‘s Rudy?

dialogues.speaker: JOE DAVID
dialogues.text: Locker room. Somethin’ to do with only havin’ one shoe. Jimmy waves for the ball from Joel.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Gimme the ball.

dialogues.text: You‘re throwin’ batting practice? (digs in) Man...talk about bein’ in the right place at the right time. Jimmy throws a pitch...nothing special. WHAM! Wack tags i deep into the outfield, a scorching line drive. JOAQUIN (CONT’D} (and the trash talk begins) That ball's gonna land in a new timezone. (waits for the next pitch) Hey Coach! Might want to re-set your watch before this next one. Jimmy looks in at Joel. Joel looks out at Jimmy. They’re thinking the same thing. Joel opens and closes his mitt - “feed me”. Jimmy drops his head a bit so that Wack can't the smile on his face.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He wipes it off, goes into his wind-up and brings the hea The ball comes in so fast it gives off a hissing sound...

dialogues.speaker: THWACK
dialogues.text: ».,and it hits Joel’s glove. Wack’s knees buckle, The tra talk is over. JOAQUIN (CONT‘D) (to Joel) What was that man?

dialogues.speaker: JOEL
dialogues.text: Wait’ll he warms up.

dialogues.speaker: JOAQUIN
dialogues.text: Lemme see another one of those. *

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Nah. This is battin’ practice, not * pitchin’ practice. * Jimmy makes a leisurely throw to the plate. Wack knocks i solidly into the outfield, but without the trash talk. *

dialogues.text: It‘s almost dusk as Jimmy pulls his truck in front of Wac home; a small duplex of sorts featuring a broken gutter a Plywood overhang drooping above the door.

dialogues.speaker: JOAQUIN
dialogues.text: That fastball. That‘s what I'm gonna have * to get used to, huh?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: You will. Takes time.

dialogues.speaker: JOAQUIN
dialogues.text: (hops out of the truck) Thanks for the ride. Wack's four-year-old SISTER, delighted to see him, runs f the front door.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER
dialogues.text: Wahkee! --and the attitude and trash-talking is gone, replaced by the caring brother. Jimmy watches Joaquin scoop his siste into his arms and whirl her around. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOAQUIN
dialogues.text: {in Spanish) Little sister. “Whatcha doin’ out here?

dialogues.speaker: SISTER

dialogues.speaker: LORRT
dialogues.text: It's Fort Worth. High school coaching jobs don‘t get any better. He stares out the window. LORRI (CONT’D) You get to coach, get to teach, and not that it’s the most important thing in life, Jimmy, but... it is twice the money. And we could sure use it.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I know. Lorri isn't sure what to say. She rolls back onto her pil

dialogues.speaker: LORRI
dialogues.text: Well I'm done tellin’ you to sleep on it, ‘cause that sure ain't workin’.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The baseball field awaits...dew-covered and pristine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silent tension fills the locker room as each player liste to Jimmy finish his pre-game speech.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Three years ago this program finished the season with one win. Two years ago one more. And last year...same story. ' (leoks at his players) This year we've won sixteen games. The only sound is the chomping of gum.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Gentlemen...we need seventeen. A few nods.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Alright, anybody have any questions? None...until... ‘ (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: JOAQUIN ’ Coach? { {long pause) You comin’ back next year? “It’s the last question Jimmy wanted to hear.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Let‘s worry about this year first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The P-A microphone awaits the call of the game. A few inc away: the school library's REEL TO REEL, spinning an old of THE STAR SPANGLED BANNER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The brilliant white of the chalk gieams along the first b line. Someone unseen is singing the National Anthem...

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: ..oh say does that star spangled banner yet wave... The voice is rich and on-key. The 2ig Lake team stands in precise row just on the grass. ( TITLE: DISTRICT CHAMPIONSHIP GAME . The man behind the voice comes into view Henry

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: ..o’er the lend of the free...and the home of the brave. The crowd, which now includes fans along the sidelines an behind the outfield fence, cheers in anticipation. Henry winks at Jimmy, the debt for fixing the field now settled Jimmy’s team heads for the dugout. He tries to calm them

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: We're a different team now than the last * time we played these guys. They‘re ripe * for the pickin’. Just, let’s not be ” nervous out there... (nervous himself} Nuthin‘ to be nervous about...  96 97 oo pe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ground ball scoots under the glove of a nervous Joaquin rolls between his legs into the outfield. One runner scores...then another. Joel catches the ball a holds up his glove, telling his teammates to take it easy

dialogues.speaker: SCOREBOARD
dialogues.text: Wack stands in the infield, disgusted with himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A series of sparkling plays as the game draws on, and wit each play the contest grows more intense: 1) The Owl third baseman (ERNEST) fields a hot grounder a throws the ball to Joe David for an out. 2) An Owl player (MIGUEL) hits a shot toward the opposing shortstop who stabs the ball 3) An opposing player hits a high pop-up. Joe David waves off several Owl players to make the catch 4) Rudy, on the mound, checks an opposing runner's lead-o from second base. Joel gives a signal which Wack and Miguel(2nd baseman) catch. Neither covers the bag MATT (the Owl center-fielder) sneaks up behind the runner and takes the pick-off throw from Rudy, catching the opposing runner unawares 5S) A bloop fly into right field sends Owls scurrying to and snag it. The Owl right-fielder barely misses a collis to make a diving catch and toss to Joel (covering first) double up an opposing runner. 6) A long fly ball sails close to the fence, but Matt, th Qwl center-fielder catches it over his shoulder 7) One after another opposing players strike out as Rudy gives his all on the mound. 8) One by one the Owls strike out as the Opposing pitcher finds his groove. And then -- 9) An Owl player hits the ball hard and makes it to third base. 4 triple. 10) Rudy, at the plate, takes a sign from Jimmy and steel himself for his at-bat (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He digs in, watches the wind-up then bunts - a suicide squeeze The ball trickles toward third base as the Owl runner slides under the throw.

dialogues.speaker: 2XT. BIG LAKE BASEBALL FIELD
dialogues.text: The scoreboard tells the story. Sixth inning...

dialogues.speaker: VISITORS 2 OWLS 1
dialogues.text: Big Lake runners are on second (Joe David) and third. Joa digs in at the plate as the crowd stomps its collective f on the bleachers, encouraging him on...

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Your time Wack. It's your time. The nervousness is gone, replaced by a look of confidence patiently watches one strike go by, and then another. The opposing pitcher looks like he has him...but on the n pitch, Joaquin cracks the bail down the first base line. FAIR BALL! The crowd erupts as the Owl on first trots in score. Jimmy gives Joe David the “stop” sign but Joe Davi runs right through it and scores on a close play at the Plate. Wack stays calm as he stands on second, pulling his batti glove off. But as he glances down, a hint of a smile and subtle look of pride flashes across his face

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The seventh and final inning. VISITORS 2 OWLS 3 Rudy's struggling. Opposing runners on second and third. throws a pitch.

dialogues.speaker: UMPIRE
dialogues.text: Ball four. The bases are loaded. Jimmy, Joaquin, Joel, Joe David and rest of the infielders all walk to the mound.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Last inning. How much you got left?

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: I got nuthin‘. Jce David drops his head, knowing they're now set up to l But Joaquin smells the victory...and grabs the ball from Joel's glove, plopping it in Rudy‘s. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: wu oF yt ke ont  99 100 63.

dialogues.speaker: JOAQUIN
dialogues.text: You with nuthin’ is better than anything they got. Jimmy and Rudy share a look.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: {a short beat until...} Finish it. Rudy nods. JIMMY (CONT’D) Alright...two more outs. Let’s go. Everyone heads back to their position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rudy, dead tired, throws and the batter hits a screamer r back at him. He stabs the ball and the runners hold. Two down . The next opposing batter (Cory) digs in, crowding the pla Joel notices and gives Rudy a sign. Rudy brushes the batt back. Ball one. The batter backs off the plate just a bit ~ Joel notices and Rudy freezes the batter with a curve.

dialogues.speaker: UMPIRE
dialogues.text: Strike!!! One and one Rudy's next pitch is pounded deep, deep, deep over the le field fence. Foul. One ball, two strikes. The batter reclaims the plate, digging in. challenging Ru Joel gives Rudy a look, then holds his mitt up and opens closes it. “FEED ME!” Rudy nods, squints at the batter, who blows Rudy a kiss. Cocky. Rudy ignores, sets his feet and blows a fastball b the batter, who nearly jumps out of his shoes swinging... missing. Game over! The game ends and the celebration begins. Jimmy, Hunter a the remaining bench players run onto the field as the tea dogpiles on top of Rudy.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jimmy pats a few of his players on the back, but most don even see him. Except for Wack. \ Joaquin comes over and embraces his coach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The celebration has moved into the locker room. The playe clap and watch Joe David dance. Jimmy watches with * satisfaction, leaning against a nearby wall. Rudy stands on a bench and calls for quiet. *

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: Hey! Hey!!! * {they quiet) * To the man who taught us about wantin‘ somethin’ more...Coach Jimmy Morris of the district champion Big Lake Owls! * (cheers, Jimmy smiles) We wanted it...and now we got it baby. More yelling and cheering. Rudy steps down and walks up t his coach. He holds out a BASEBALL signed by each player. RUDY (CONT‘D) Now it's your turn. f

dialogues.speaker: NL,
dialogues.text: Rudy shakes his hand and Jimmy is visibly moved. Each pla walks up, shakes his hand, and says the same words...

dialogues.speaker: PLAYERS
dialogues.text: Your turn Coach. Jimmy shakes the hand of each player. No tears, but his e can't hide what he feels for these kids. EXT.” BIG LAKE BASEBALL FIELD - DUSK 102 * Their hats on backwards, Jimmy and Hunter walk across the lush grass. Father and son are by themselves, Jimmy’s han resting on Hunter's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: HUNTER
dialogues.text: You knew they were gonna win today. Didn‘t you?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Sometimes when you want somethin’ bad enough, it works out that way.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jimmy looks out at the field, part of him knowing he may see it again. The sun dips below the horizon...and it’s t same look he had as a kid back in Florida. He slows down,

dialogues.speaker: HUNTER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: It‘s been a good field. They walk again.

dialogues.speaker: HUNTER
dialogues.text: Can we get a slurpee?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Maybe later.

dialogues.speaker: HUNTER
dialogues.text: But you said if you wanted somethin’ bad enough...

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, I wasn‘t talkin’ about slurpees. FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The school parking lot is nearly vacant. The marquee on t SIGN out front reads: HAVE A GREAT SUMMER!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is empty as Jimmy packs his things. He holds a b under one arm and is pulling some newspaper articles off bulletin board with the other. The headline from the first article reads: OWLS HEADED FO STATE TOURNAMENT . Jimmy smiles as he pulls it down. He reaches for the next OWLS LOSE STATE TOURNEY OPENER 6-4. He tucks it in the bo and reaches for the third: a small advertisement...

dialogues.speaker: JUNE 15TH SAN ANGELO STATE NIVERSITY
dialogues.text: Scrawled in the corner, a handwritten note from one of hi players: YOUR TURN COACH! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: i04 105 oO be of

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The smile fades, Jimmy knowing his players expect him to his end of the bargain. He tosses the ad in the box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 105 Jimmy, Hunter and Jessica sit at the small kitchen table eating cold cereal. Jamie is in the high chair, sloshing oatmeal everywhere. Lorri zips in, late for work.

dialogues.speaker: LORRI
dialogues.text: First day of summer registration and I‘m gonna have to skip breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA
dialogues.text: (points to a box of cereal) You can take some Mister Crunch with you.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: He's a Captain Jessie. Don‘t go bustin’ rank on him.

dialogues.speaker: LORRI
dialogues.text: Thanks anyway honey. Lorri gathers her things from the counter and asks Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: LORRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You got anything goin‘ today?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Me? Nah.

dialogues.speaker: LORRI
dialogues.text: We need to go see the real estate guy.

dialogues.speaker: HUNTER
dialogues.text: He's been a Captain forever. Why don't they make him something better?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: You thinkin’ Admiral Crunch?

dialogues.speaker: LORRI
dialogues.text: Just say “yes ma‘am"” so I at least know you heard me.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Yes ma‘am.

dialogues.speaker: LORRI
dialogues.text: Make sure you take ‘em all if you go. You kids mind your daddy, okay? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She's out the door, barely hearing the “okay’s” coming fr the kitchen table. Jimmy pours some more cereal.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: {to Hunter) Remind me not to forget Jamie if we go see the real estate guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An endless highway stretches out of Big Lake, straight as be into the early morning high desert. Jimmy’s truck roll past a sign that reads...

dialogues.speaker: SAN ANGELO 97 MILES
dialogues.text: ...quickly fading into the heat rising from the asphait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy and the kids are in the old truck; Hunter in the fr Jessie and Jamie in the tiny extended cab seats in the ba The truck moves closer to the try-out field and, for a sh moment, it looks as if only a handful of players are ther ...until they get closer and see the field filled with yo players. What little confidence Jimmy had...slips away.

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA
dialogues.text: They got lots of players Daddy Jimmy reluctantly pulls in, as far from the field as he c get. He sits inside, staring at the players, each with th drive and conditioning he had years ago. The truck idles for a few seconds...and Jimmy’s hand slid on to the stick shift, ready to slip it into reverse. He glances at Hunter...and the look from his son tells him everything The truck stays. The keys turn...the engine falls silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The young player at the front of the registration line si in. The BASEBALL SCOUT behind the fold-out table says...

dialogues.speaker: BASEBALL SCOUT
dialogues.text: We'll call your name. Jimmy moves to the head of the line; Hunter and Jessie on each side of him, Jamie in a STROLLER in front of him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BASEBALL SCOUT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have your players get in-line Coach. Everybody signs in. Another scout seated nearby recognizes Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: BASEBALL SCOUT
dialogues.text: Jim Morris? {Jimmy turns) Doug Gassoway. I saw you when the Brewers drafted you...must have been, what?...

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Awhile back. How you doin‘ Doug. (shakes his hand) You still lookin’ at players?

dialogues.speaker: GASSOWAY
dialogues.text: Lookin’s the easy part. It’s the findin’ that gives me trouble. (smiles, short beat) You bring some kids? (glances at Hunter and company) ‘Sides your own?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: (hesitant) I‘m here for me.

dialogues.speaker: GASSOWAY
dialogues.text: (laughs) For you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun rises high in the sky as Jimmy and the kids sit i the bleachers watching the other players try-out The infielders make sparkling plays, the outfielders easy grabs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy and the kids now sit on the grass beyond the fence, catching the shade from the scoreboard. The try-out goes on. Jessie has a sheet of paper filled w TIC-TAC-TOE games.

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA
dialogues.text: You can be “X" this time Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: f

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jimmy sits next to her and absently scribbles an “xX,” mo his attention directed toward the field. EXT. SAN ANGELO BASEBALL FIELD - DAY lll The baseball scout holds a RADAR GUN on one of the prospe The pitch comes in...and the number flashes: 84. The young pitcher catches the ball. He tosses again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .,.and Jimmy catches the ball, as he plays a lazy game of catch with Hunter. Jessie and Jamie slumber in the shade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The weather is hot, hot enough that a few of the players water on their head to cool down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another pitch comes in. The radar gun lights up...85.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hunter sits on the open tailgate of the truck. He’s worki on a can of soda..,looking down...at something. It‘s his father...changing Jamie’s diaper.

dialogues.speaker: HUNTER
dialogues.text: We’re outta diapers.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: (reluctantly cleaning) We're outta here...soon as Jamie's good to go.

dialogues.speaker: HUNTER
dialogues.text: But Dad...

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: ..no “but dad‘s”, okay? I'm dealin’ with enough “butts” as it is. Jimmy looks up and knows he has to be delicate. JIMMY (CONT’D) Listen Hunter,...I promised to try out. There‘s nuthin‘ I can do if they don’t want to look. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: From the field...

dialogues.speaker: GASSOWAY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Jim! 70. 1is Jimmy stands, wet wipe in hand, and sees Gassoway waving in from the pitching mound. He looks at Hunter...

dialogues.speaker: HUNTER
dialogues.text: I‘m not doin’ it.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: - Just...keep her here. This won‘t take long. He tosses the wipe in the truck bed and grabs his glove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy jogs the last couple of steps to the mound.

dialogues.speaker: GASSOWAY
dialogues.text: You need to warm up? Jimmy, knowing it won’t take long, stretches his arm behi his head...not even close to your textbook warm up

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Nah, I’m good.

dialogues.speaker: GASSOWAY
dialogues.text: {flips him the ball) Don’t hurt yourself Gassoway walks away, leaving Jimmy alone on the mound. He stretches his arm out again and looks in; the catcher already crouched behind the plate, the scout holding the radar gun behind the back-stop.

dialogues.speaker: BASEBALL SCOUT
dialogues.text: Whenever you‘re ready. Jimmy takes a deep breath. He hears Jamie let go with an impatient cry and closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Whenever I'm ready. And Jimmy lets loose. ssssssSSSSSS...THUMP! The ball smac hard into the catcher’s glove, loud enough that a couple heads turn from around the field. 116

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Hunter, standing in the truck bed (so he can see), smiles The catcher holds the glove still for a moment, surprised the sound. Without a word, he slowly throws the ball back Jimmy catches it and scuffs the pitching rubber with his foot. He exhales, letting his shoulders fall, and throws again... THWACK! More heads turn. The scout with the radar gun sho little reaction, aside from his eyes quickly reading the unseen number. Another pitch...POP! Players continue to turn and stare. pitches come faster...and faster. THWACK! THWACK! Gassoway moves alongside the baseball sco checking out the radar gun numbers without expression. Pitch...pop. Pitch...pop. Jimmy looks in...now relaxed.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You want me to keep goin’?

dialogues.speaker: GASSOWAY
dialogues.text: Couple more. All of the remaining players are now watching. Both Gasso and the scout are holding radar guns. Each pitch piles on top of the other, faster...faster GASSOWAY (CONT’D) * That's good, Jim. * The try-out ends. Jimmy walks from the mound and the youn man who was catching pulls off his mask and jogs out.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG CATCHER
dialogues.text: You were throwin’ hard man.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: (scoffs) C'mon...

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG CATCHER
dialogues.text: Yeah, well you got ‘em talkin’ Jimmy looks behind the plate and sees that Gassoway and t scout are talking...intently.  127

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy puckles Jamie inside. He holds a diaper in one han he heads for the garbage. Gassoway is waiting for him.

dialogues.speaker: GASSOWAY
dialogues.text: Jim, how fast were you throwin’ fifteen years ago?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Slow enough that scouts stopped usin‘ the word “fast.” He tosses the diaper in the garbage and as it hits the bottom...the question is asked again.

dialogues.speaker: GASSOWAY
dialogues.text: Jim... {Jimmy turns) ...how fast were you throwin’?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: (sees he's serious) 84, 85. Why?

dialogues.speaker: GASSOWAY
dialogues.text: You just threw 98 miles an hour.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: (stunned) What?

dialogues.speaker: GASSOWAY
dialogues.text: Dozen straight pitches. Two radar guns. Same thing on both.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Doug... there's no way I was throwin’...

dialogues.speaker: GASSOWAY
dialogues.text: ...I know. I've been a scout for a long time and rule number one is...arms slow down when they get old.. Jimmy can’t say a word.

dialogues.speaker: GASSOWAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Listen Jim,...I call the office and tell ‘em I got a guy almost twice these kids age...I‘m gonna get laughed at... (beat) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a. a in (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GASSOWAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: .,.but if I don’t call in a 98 mile an hour fastball...I‘m gonna get fired. (another beat) I'm just lettin’ you know there’s a chance you’1l get a call on this. Gassoway shakes his head and starts to walk away.

dialogues.speaker: GASSOWAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You figure out what I saw out there today, you let me know...okay?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: (still stunned) Okay. Jimmy is left alone with about a million thoughts. He gla over at the now empty field, then turns his eyes to his t where Hunter and Jessie are chasing each other round and round. When Jamie starts crying the picture is complete. Jimmy's not 20 anymore. What the hell, he smiles anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lorri uses her back to shove open the kitchen door, groce sacks taking up both arms. She plops down the sacks on th counter and punches the TELEPHONE ANSWERING MACHINE. She starts pulling groceries from the bag...

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY ON THE MACHINE, (V.C.)
dialogues.text: Hey...don‘t fix dinner, we‘re gettin‘ some pizza. ..but the next few messages stop her cold. . ANSWERING MACHINE (vV.0O.) Jim, this is Dan Jennings with the Tampa Bay Devil Rays. I’1l try back later... (beep) cim, Mark Peterson with the Tampa lay Devil Rays. Doug Gassoway told me about this afternoon. I'll try you first thing in the morning... (beep) Jim, it’s Doug. We‘re gonna have you throw again in a couple of days, just to make sure. They‘re sendin’ out one of the boys from Tampa... She stares at the machine. stem  119 74.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kids pile through the door, Jessica barely able to ho the pizza. She puts it on the counter, proudly announcing

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA
dialogues.text: Daddy told me to give you the pizza and mot say anything else.

dialogues.speaker: LORRI
dialogues.text: Thank you sweet pea... {eyes Jimmy as he enters) - ...I’m sure that’s exactly what he told you. Lorri looks at Jimmy as she opens the pizza box. Jimmy's smiling like the cat who ate the canary. Hunter is silently bursting...

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Alright, go ahead... ...and the story floods out. Hunter spills beans everywhe as Jimmy and Lorri share a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pizza-stained plates surround the cable, the kids already bed. Jim and Lorri remain...

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: (still in disbelief) -and when he said 98... (shakes his head) Do you know how many guys throw 98 miles an hour? His side of the conversation has an almost dreamy tone to as if he’s still recalling every pitch as he gazes at the candle in the middle of the cable.

dialogues.speaker: LORRI
dialogues.text: Not many?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Count ‘em on one hand. (beat} I still can‘t believe it. I mean, those are major league scouts on cur message machine. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: eR HOF *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: bee +t # ee

dialogues.speaker: LORRI
dialogues.text: I know. It’s great. She asks delicately...

dialogues.speaker: LORRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Listen hon, um, why didn’t you tell me about all this?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Well, I was worried there might be quite a bit of laughter involved. Lorri smiles, politely.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It was just this...this thing to get the kids playin’ is all. I figured I'd throw a few pitches and I’d be done with it.

dialogues.speaker: LORRI
dialogues.text: (keeps it together) So...you’re considering this? Jimmy's been so wrapped up in the warm memory of the try- that he realizes he hasn’t given that part of it a lot of thought .

dialogues.speaker: TIMMY
dialogues.text: I don’t know,... It's just..-.never thrown that hard before. Lorri nods, tries to smile.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: LORRI
dialogues.text: Hmm?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: You just don’t seem too excited.

dialogues.speaker: LORRI
dialogues.text: No, I am. Really. She walks around the table and hugs Jimmy from behind,

dialogues.speaker: LORRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It‘s just been a long time since you played.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pare

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: You know what was the hardest thing about givin’ it up? (after a beat) Givin‘ it up without knowin’ The look on Lorri’'s face shows she’s conflicted about th whole thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The glow of the television set shines on Jimmy's face as watches a baseball game. On the screen...the gate to the bullpen opens and a relie pitcher jogs toward the pitching mound. Jimmy watches the short journey... ... givin’ it up without knowin’”...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's pouring rain, a warm Texas storm dumping heavy drops the try~out field from two days earlier. Jimmy wears a TEE-SHIRT and WORKOUT PANTS, already soaked he throws from the mound. His foot slips a bit in the mud...but the ball sails in hard. Gassoway and TWO OTHER SCOUTS stand behind the backstop a all THREE RADAR GUNS read 96 miles per hour. Hunter sits in the bleachers behind the three scouts, try to read the speed. The pitches keep coming. ..96...97...

dialogues.speaker: GASSOWAY
dialogues.text: So much for his arm falling off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The try-out ends. Jimmy walks toward the dug-out and smil at Hunter, waiting with his duffel bag and a towel...a lo of pride on his face. He reaches for the towel, playfully using it to rub his s head. And as he starts to dry his own face...he notices.. ..an OLD TRUCK discreetly parked beyond the outfield fenc His father’s truck. It slowly backs up and pulls away. om (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jimmy gazes out, but not for long. Gassoway walks in the other side of the dug-out

dialogues.speaker: GASSOWAY
dialogues.text: dim... Jimmy turns...and waits... GASSOWAY (CONT’D) We‘re ready to sign you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: First pitch of the game...low. Bali one

dialogues.text: Jimmy Sits with the rest of the relief pitchers. Most don even care about the game, but Jimmy gazes intently at the game on the field taking in every moment

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The game continues...a series of plays unfolding ** BR ground ball struck to the Texas shortstop, who scco up and turns a precise double play ** The Tampa Bay pitcher throwing a dazzling curve ball a the umpire calling out

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lorri and the kids applaud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ** BR Texas batter laces a single into the outfield and t rumner on third base trots home.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: .,.and the Rangers break through in the third inning to take a one nothing lead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The RANGERS’ MANAGER and the other players congratulate t runner who scored as he steps into the dugout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The game continues.. ** A Tampa batter hits a long fly ball, but it‘s short of fence. The Texas outfielder catches it. ** B Texas batter hits an even longer fly ball and this o sails over the fence for a home-run

dialogues.speaker: RADIO ANNOUNCER, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: ...that one is gone! A three run homer and that gives Texas a four nothing lead in the sixth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy‘s head drops. The bullpen phone rings and the TAMPA PITCHING COACH answers it. He nods and yells outc..

dialogues.speaker: TAMPA COACH
dialogues.text: Blanton, Rodriguez Two relief pitchers get up and start to throw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Texas surge continues as a batter drives a Tampa pitc deep into the outfield. It drops in and the Devil Ray fielders scramble to throw it back in.  200 201 204 205 206 207 117

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bianton is called in...and he walks through the open gate onto the field. Jimmy watches his teammate jog out from the bullpen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ** A Tampa batter, Canseco, finally gets hold of a pitch drives it deep into the upper deck of the stadium. He bre into his home~run trot. ** Blanton throws a pitch, but it misses the mark. The ba strolls to first

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy continues to wait in the bullpen...and it’s at that moment that the PHONE RINGS AGAIN. The coach picks it up. listens, and hangs up. He nods toward Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: TAMPA BAY PITCHING COACH
dialogues.text: Morris. Start warmin' up. Jimmy blinks, but without any more hesitation, stands up pulls off his windbreaker. He starts to throw..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and the players and the townspeople spot him immediate cheering and pointing his way

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy throws, hoping to shake away the nerves as well as stiffness that’s set in from sitting all game

dialogues.speaker: EXT, ARLINGTON BASEBALL FIELD
dialogues.text: Blanton, the fatigue obvious, wipes his forehead with the back of his jersey sleeve. He throws one more pitch. A ball

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy throws...the ball smacks the catcher’s glove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lorri's enough of a fan to know what might happen. She st up.  208 209 210

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blanton throws another pitch. Another ball

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy throws...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blanton throws. Ball four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Tampa manager runs from the dugout and then looks out the bullpen. He points to his left arm, a signal that he wants the left-handed pitcher... .. Jimmy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pitching coach turns and looks right at Jimmy...

dialogues.speaker: TAMPA BAY PITCHING COACH
dialogues.text: Morris. You‘re in. ..and Jimmy sees the gate swing open, only this time, it’ for him. The noise seems louder, more intense. He jogs through the gate and runs toward the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Big Lake section is delirious...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .-while Lorri holds her hands to her lips in a stunned, almost prayer~-like fashion

dialogues.speaker: EXT ARLINGTON BASEBALL FIELD
dialogues.text: The dream moment. Jimmy makes the run he thought he’d mak many years ago; the lights bright, the colors vivid, the sound embracing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moment is captured on the video monitors inside the p box...reporters watching, more than a few caught up at th sight. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: C , RADIO ANNOUNCER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And here he is, the high school science teacher from Big Lake, Texas, Jim Morris...making his major league debut... 213B EXT. ARLINGTON BASEBALL FIELD — NIGHT 213B Jimmy arrives at the mound, the Tampa manager and the cat waiting for him. He’s scared...and the manager knows it. The noise of the crowd surrounds him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TAMPA MANAGER
dialogues.text: Little louder than back home?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: A little, yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: TAMPA MANAGER
dialogues.text: Well then, let's not make this too hard. Rimember that fastball you were showin‘ me before the game? Jimmy nods. TAMPA MANAGER (CONT‘D) I need three of ‘em. The manager gives him the ball. The catcher nods in suppo and runs back to home plate...and Jimmy is all alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joaquin and the kids yell out

dialogues.speaker: KIDS
dialogues.text: C'mon Coach!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry, Frank and Cal watch...

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Let’s get ‘em Jimmy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Texas batter digs his feet into the batter’s box, eye Jimmy with confidence Jimmy steps from the mound for a second, his back to home that he can work the ball with both hands...and keep the hitter from seeing the nervous look on his face He turns back. .and puts his foor on the pitching rubber The batter stares out...calm, assured. Jimmy throws...a fastball. The batter doesn’t swing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy's cheering section yells out. Lorri, the kids...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy catches the ball and paces around the mound again. rubs the ball some more. The Texas batter steps back in...still confident. Jimmy goes into his wind up and throws again. This time t batter swings...but misses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy’s old team and the townspeople are on their feet, t applause even louder than before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Tampa catcher throws the ball back and Jimmy takes another lap around the mound The batter‘s look of confidence isn’t what it was a coupl pitches ago. Jimmy comes back to the mound and the catcher signals for another fastball Another hard pitch to the plate. The batter swings...and a foul ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Texas manager calmly looks out, his catcher seated ne to him.

dialogues.speaker: TEXAS MANAGER
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: TEXAS CATCHER
dialogues.text: (matter-of-fact) He can pitch.

dialogues.speaker: EXT ARLINGTON BALLPARK STANDS
dialogues.text: Lorri and the kids nervously wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy comes to the mound one more time, surrounded by a c noise he’s never experienced before. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: e@ The look of confidence on the hitter’s face has been r with a look of sheer concentration, Jimmy looks in... ...throws... ..and the batter swings. And MISSES. The crowd erupts. Jimmy exhales and walks from the mound, shortstop coming up behind and giving him a simple pat on back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But there’s nothing simple about the celebration in the stands as Jimmy‘s high school team exchanges high-fives w older folks from the town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lorri claps...so proud of her husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy walks into the dugout and receives the congratulati @ of his new teammates, the final pat on the back coming BROOKS . The applause surrounding him now comes from Tampa and Tex fans alike...paying tribute to his accomplishment He sits on the bench and shakes his head, suddenly realiz what just happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy stands in front of his locker, surrounded by REPORT The showers have long since grown quiet...and he wears th blue sport coat and tie, a duffel bag draped over his shoulder

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: Jim,..what pitches did you throw to get that strikeout .

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Fastball, fastball, fastball...and... {pretends to think) .. fastball. @ The reporters laugh. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: How'd it feel? Pitchin’ in the major leagues?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: (waits a second before...) Like I hoped it would. The reporters are packed so tightly around Jimmy that he only see faces, cameras and microphones. Bue through a tiny crack in the pack of reporters...he se standing in the hallway, very patiently, watching...

dialogues.speaker: HIS FATHER
dialogues.text: and the remaining questions go unheard. JIMMY (CONT’D} Excuse me Jimmy cuts through the swarm of reporters and out into.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His father offers an awkward smile, uncertain of what to or perhaps worse, uncertain of what he might hear..

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I didn’t know you were here. JIM SR. Wasn‘t missin’ this one. Jimmy doesn’t respond...doesn’‘t want to hurt him anymore Sr. struggles with the words, barely making eye contact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watchin’ you tonight The look in his eyes softens. He’s seeing it again, so pr

dialogues.speaker: JIM SR., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ..mot many fathers get a chance to do that. {as close as he'll come to breaking) Guess I let too many of those things get away. A long pause. Jimmy bails him out (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: So did I. The words are out. Jimmy gazes at his father with a respe that was always just below the surface. A half-nod from Jim Sr., his expression showing how very proud he is to be Jimmy’s father. JIM SR. Well then... He turns to walk away..

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Dad? Jim Sr. stops and looks back. Jimmy reaches in a pocket o the duffel bag and pulls out THE BASEBALL from the game. Instead of the hug, instead of the handshake, Jimmy hands most precious item from his most precious moment...to his father.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thanks for comin’. The gesture says everything for both of them. Jim Sr. nod again, a nod of acceptance and respect. He walks away and Jimmy watches him go. And for the first time, his expression offers hope for their relationship. Jimmy glances the other direction, just a glance, and see Lorri standing there. She saw it all. He hikes the duffel bag higher on his shoulder and walks over...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and Lorri smiles as he moves closer.

dialogues.speaker: LORRI
dialogues.text: Does this mean I don’t get a ball? He kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: S‘all I got left

dialogues.speaker: LORRI
dialogues.text: Girl could do worse. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 1 bh ba : They starz to walk.

dialogues.speaker: LORRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So...how’s it feel bein’ the oldest rookie in the last thirty years?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Let’s see...I‘m tired, my back’s sore, I got reporters everywhere...so, all in all... (beat) ..I'd say things are pretty good.

dialogues.speaker: LORRI
dialogues.text: You looked good out there. For an old guy She reaches for his hand.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Where the kids?

dialogues.speaker: LORRI
dialogues.text: Well...Hunter’s with Henry, Jessie‘’s with Frank and Jamie‘’s with Cal

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: You left Jamie with Cal?

dialogues.speaker: LORRI
dialogues.text: He's got a little help Lorri pushes the door open...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and Jimmy sees half the town of Big Lake waiting to gr him - He walks into the crowd of familiar faces: young and old, and women. all sharing the same joy at having seén one ma dream come true. At having seen their dream come true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The celebration goes on for a short time more and the sou fades toward silence as a spray of CONFETTI fills the air hear the first piano chords of “THE CHRISTMAS SONG” by Na King Cole as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE MOVE toward the school ~ past the sidewalk, past the s past the flagpole, across the lawn, up to the window and

dialogues.speaker: 229D INSIDE THE SCHOOL MAIN HALLWAY 229D
dialogues.text: Where we move in on -- The TEAM PHOTOGRAPH of the Big Lake Owls; five players kneeling in front, five standing in back, with their coac Jimmy Morris, standing on the right hand side. As we pull back -~- ...the song continues... The photo slowly grows smaller, revealing a frame around It grows smaller still, revealing a TAMPA BAY JERSEY moun behind. And as the black and white photograph slowly grows distan the other items in the school trophy case come into view. A smattering of football trophies...pushed to one side... SUPER: tbd FADE OUT.
